awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Feasibility Study of a Reduced Order Model for Calculating Fractional Flow Reserve (FFR) Using Angiographic Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to improve the clinical care of patients suffering from coronary artery disease (CAD) and to reduce the associated costs. CAD remains the most common form of heart disease, afflicting more than 18 million adults and costing the U.S. healthcare system over $90 billion annually. Advances in diagnostics to improve treatment decisions have lagged behind advances in therapies. The proposed research will explore novel computational modeling methods within an artificial intelligence (AI) software platform to improve diagnosis and optimize patient-specific treatment decisions. Value propositions are to improve clinical outcomes, reduce healthcare costs, and save lives. The software will provide competitive advantages as a more user-friendly and non-invasive diagnostic method capable of faster and more accurate clinical assessment of CAD than existing alternatives. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will advance the diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) to optimize patient-specific treatment decisions. CAD patients typically undergo an angiography procedure whereby coronary arteries are visualized to estimate stenosis severity and make subjective treatment decisions on whether to perform revascularization procedures (e.g., stenting or bypass graft surgeries). More recently Fractional Flow Reserve (FFR), a measure of the pressure gradient across the vessel stenosis, has demonstrated improved outcomes when guiding treatment decisions. However, adoption of FFR remains modest given shortcomings of available interventional devices and cost. Recently, commercial efforts have developed computer-based methods to estimate FFR non-invasively, although with limited accuracy in borderline values of FFR. The proposed research will develop and calibrate a Reduced Order Model (ROM) using novel machine learning and computational methods to provide FFR measures in a faster, more accurate, and more integrated manner with clinical workflows than existing solutions. The ROM will rely on recent advances in Graph Theory to enhance a 1D nonlinear formulation of blood flow. The method will be calibrated using synthetic data generated with ground truth 3D Navier-Stokes solutions and validated against clinical measurements of FFR from a cohort of 20 patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, AngioInsight has, in partnership with the University of Michigan, developed artificial intelligence techniques to non-invasively and rapidly diagnose the severity of certain types of coronary artery disease (CAD). Advancements in cardiovascular medical device and biopharmaceutical therapies have saved lives and improved quality of lives for CAD patients.  Yet CAD remains the most common form of heart disease, which is the leading cause of death for women and men and individuals of most racial and ethnic groups in the US. Along with the more than 18 million adults afflicted by CAD in the US each year, CAD was responsible for over 365,000 deaths during year 2017 and burdens the US healthcare system with $89 billion in direct medical costs each year.  Fractional flow reserve (FFR) is an invasive procedure performed with a catheter that has been demonstrated to improve CAD treatment decision. However, shortcomings related to time, risks and cost of invasive FFR guidewires, and workflow disruption and questionable accuracy of early competitive offerings for non-invasive competitive FFR software have limited market adoption. The AI software created in this project is based on a combination of a small set of anonymized patient data on vascular geometries and FFR measurements, as well as high-fidelity computational fluid dynamics simulations on a large set of synthetically generated geometries. It will lead to an improvement of the process of diagnosis of the severity of stenoses in patients via a practical utilization of FFR through rapid and accurate results. This will allow cardiologists to fully benefit from the diagnostic value of FFR. The development of AI-based, computational, non-invasive diagnostic tools will decisively impact the future of health care, reducing costs, and making them easier to deploy to low-income communities where current technology is beyond their reach, paving the road to democratizing healthcare. Furthermore, this project has led to high-quality, validated AI-based software tools that could be applied to several areas that are technologically important in engineering as well as critical for the advancement of computational medicine: image processing, computational modeling of blood flow, and cardiovascular outcomes research to name a few.

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2024
Modified by: Serafin Samson
